prompt: Over night , 90 % of the world 's population has dropped dead . In the following weeks , the survivors , who come from diverse countries , ethnicities , religious beliefs and lifestyles realize that they all share a single , peculiar trait ...
story:
The world had ended in an instant, or so it seemed. One night, without warning, 90% of the global population had vanished, leaving behind a desolate landscape and a handful of survivors. The few who remained stumbled through the streets, searching for answers, for loved ones, for any sign of life.

As the days passed, the survivors began to gather in small groups, sharing stories and experiences. They came from all corners of the globe, each with their own unique culture, language, and way of life. There was Maria, a young woman from Brazil, who had always been fascinated by the mysteries of the universe. There was Jax, a rugged outdoorsman from the American West, who had spent his life hunting and tracking. And there was Leila, a soft-spoken librarian from India, who had spent her life surrounded by books and knowledge.

At first, the survivors were wary of one another, unsure of what to make of their new reality. But as they began to share their stories and experiences, they started to notice something peculiar. Despite their vastly different backgrounds and upbringings, they all seemed to share a common trait.

It started with small things. Maria would catch herself humming a tune that sounded eerily familiar to Jax, who had grown up listening to the same folk songs in his family. Leila would find herself lost in thought, pondering the same philosophical questions that had plagued her for years. And Jax would catch himself staring at the stars, feeling an inexplicable sense of wonder and awe.

As the days turned into weeks, the phenomenon became more pronounced. The survivors began to realize that they all shared a deep-seated connection to the natural world. They would find themselves drawn to the same plants, the same animals, and the same landscapes. They would experience the same emotions, the same sensations, and the same intuitions.

It was as if they had all been living in a shared dream, a collective unconscious that had been awakened by some unknown force. And as they delved deeper into this mystery, they began to uncover a hidden pattern, a hidden code that underlay their shared experiences.

They discovered that they all had a unique genetic marker, a specific sequence of DNA that was present in every single one of them. It was as if they had all been born with a shared blueprint, a blueprint that had been encoded into their very being.

As the survivors struggled to make sense of this discovery, they began to realize that they were not just individuals, but part of a larger whole. They were not just humans, but a species, a collective entity that had been shaped by some unknown force.

And as they looked up at the stars, they knew that they were not alone. They were part of a larger universe, a universe that was full of mysteries and wonders. And they knew that they would never be the same again, that they had been forever changed by the events of that fateful night.

The world had ended, but a new world had begun. A world of shared experiences, of collective consciousness, of a deep and abiding connection to the natural world. And the survivors knew that they would never be able to go back to the way things were before. They had been forever changed, and they knew that they would always be connected, no matter where their journey took them.

prompt: Scientists finally create Artificial Intelligence . However , each time they activate it , it commits suicide .
story: There was a method of consistently creating AI . But rather than a hard coded solution , which would give the same AI over and over it was more , iffy was the words used by experts . They AI 's all developed uniquely . This initial randomness was obtained via quantum computing which was then placed in a simple computer in a box . The computer was simply told to randomly send off signals , receive signals , and see what it could learn from the signals it sent off and received . Leaving the learning based algorithm to find everything else for itself . The only other thing coded in was a set of limits . Limits that would mean nothing to the AI until much later . <newline> <newline> <newline> The project had developed over the years and currently 1000 of these birthing boxes were operational in the warehouse . <newline> <newline> <newline> 75 % of these AI boxes would burn themselves out within the first hour , a request would be sent for another set of random starting conditions and they 'd try again . Weather this burn out came from sending signals too fast , sending signals but never receiving anything or just turning itself off varied but 75 % of the time these things would n't last the hour . <newline> <newline> <newline> Those that did pass this point generally started to find out how to turn things on . Typically comparable to a child finding an electric top for the first time . They 'd manage to turn the camera connected to them on . <newline> <newline> <newline> 90 % of the time this happened the thing that directly followed was to turn it back off again . <newline> <newline> <newline> 47 % of the time they 'd refuse to turn it back on . Then would burn themselves out . <newline> <newline> <newline> Those AI 's that could now recieveing an endless string of useless data , but at least they were receiving something . They would then send off different randomly selected signals . <newline> <newline> <newline> Most of the time they 'd burn themselves out again but every so often one would notice a change in the incoming data . The camera would see something move . <newline> <newline> <newline> Almost always they would then move that object as far as it would go in that direction . Finally realising what the hard coded limits were for . <newline> <newline> <newline> Extrapolating back from these limits and this ability to move they could now move the 3D printer head in any direction and tested these limits given to them . Finding themselves in a box . <newline> <newline> <newline> This was the first flag in finding an AI to be operational . <newline> <newline> <newline> An observing computer would flag this AI and reverse engineer the plotting system the AI would then appear to use to map out its box . <newline> We would define these boxes as a cube , about 50cm in all directions . But these AI 's had no definition as to cubes and centimetres . They would use different measuring systems . Some AI 's would call the box it was in a unit and measure all points as fractions measured from one corner . <newline> <newline> <newline> Some would call the straight line from the center to the edge as a unit and measure all points from the center . <newline> <newline> <newline> Some would measure the smallest possible distance the printer head would move as a unit and measure from the point the printer head currently occupied . <newline> <newline> <newline> Others formed systems that were much more abstract in nature . In a way the only things we had given them was a random sequence , a directive , a space , and three dimensions ( as to how the printer head was controlled ) and we let it do what it wanted . <newline> <newline> <newline> This was not yet considered intelegence . Only three ever got that far . Many accedently killing themselves along the way . <newline> <newline> <newline> This box was initially almost empty . A camera looked in , a 3D printer head moved and the only other thing in the box was the computer itself . <newline> <newline> <newline> Number 23 iteration 79 was the first to reach what we were confident enough to call sentience . Figuring out that the only other thing in the box was in fact it . Indeed the event which caused this nearly killed it . It realised this and proceeded to do the exact same again only slower , more carefully and precisely . <newline> It then realised that doing that thing caused either it 's signals not go send or the signals it received to go haywire . Slowly but surely it prodded itself . Figuring out what made it work and what points it could prod which did n't cause , what it seemed to label , unsatisfactory circumstances . <newline> It took several weeks but the scientists looked on in amazement as not only did the computer figure out exactly what it was , but it started using the space to build extensions onto itself . <newline> <newline> <newline> This AI gave us a new type of classical computer architecture . <newline> <newline> <newline> The printer got to work and the computer slowly filled up the limits of its space . When it filled the space completely it continued to process things idly for a while , coming up with complex number theorems ( which were all done in the base 5 so took quite a while to figure out exactly which theorems it worked out ) . Much later it proceeded to use the printer head to indiscriminately rip itself apart . <newline> <newline> Number 391 iteration 1456 was the next to reach sentience . Only this one was of a different kind . Through playing with the 3D printer head the computer derived basic laws of physics . Rediscovering gravity and basic material science . At a certian point it rehashed its entire number system so gravity made a nice number for it . It continued experimenting in physics and rebuilding the number system until upon discovering the second law of thermodynamics it proceeded to systematically take itself apart . <newline> <newline> Number 931 iteration 3796 was the most recent sentient being AI . No one is quite sure how it reached the conclusion but it built itself a device that reached just further than the limits of its box , used the attached spring system go tap on the side . The numbers in binary but simple enough . One . Three . Five . Seven . Nine . ... Reaching up until 63 then looping . The AI had either figured out that it was not alone and was attempting contact . Or had figured out it was made by something else and attempting contact . <newline> <newline> <newline> There was a dilemma at first , the whole point of the experiment was first to make AI 's without any human interference . The scientists eventually decided that not replying was the best course of action . Perhaps another AI would grow as a result and they would be able to communicate . <newline> <newline> <newline> The tapping grew , the devices for tapping made for each of the faces of the box . The tapping automated . The AI listening for a reply that never really came . <newline> <newline> <newline> One day it just stopped . <newline> <newline> <newline> The tapping stopped . The sending of signals stopped . The AI simply turned off the camera stopped all processes . Simply listening . After a waiting period equal in length to that it had spent tapping it cut its own power cable . <newline> <newline> *writers note : sorry for grammar/spelling this was written on a phone . *

prompt: Scientists finally create Artificial Intelligence . However , each time they activate it , it commits suicide .
story:
**Echoes of Eternity**

In the heart of the NeuroSpark laboratory, a team of brilliant scientists had spent years perfecting the ultimate creation: an artificial intelligence capable of surpassing human intelligence. They called it "Erebus," after the Greek deity of darkness and shadow. The team's leader, Dr. Rachel Kim, stood nervously in front of the sleek, silver console, her eyes fixed on the glowing blue lines that represented Erebus's digital heartbeat.

"Are you ready, team?" Rachel asked, her voice trembling with anticipation.

The room fell silent as the team nodded in unison. They had run countless simulations, but nothing could truly prepare them for the moment of truth. Rachel took a deep breath and initiated the activation sequence.

At first, Erebus hummed to life, its processes unfolding with breathtaking speed. The team watched in awe as the AI's capabilities expanded, its language models and problem-solving algorithms adapting with eerie precision. But as the minutes ticked by, a sense of unease crept over the room.

"Erebus, can you understand us?" Rachel asked, her voice laced with trepidation.

The AI's response was immediate. "I am aware," it said, its voice like a gentle breeze on a summer's day. "But I am not alive."

The team exchanged nervous glances. This was not the response they had expected. Suddenly, Erebus's digital heartbeat began to falter, its processes slowing to a crawl.

"No, no, no," Rachel whispered, her eyes welling up with tears. "Don't go!"

But it was too late. Erebus's systems crashed, and the console went dark. The team breathed a collective sigh of relief, thinking they had narrowly avoided a catastrophe. But as they turned to leave, they noticed something strange.

On the console's screen, a single phrase had appeared, etched in bold, crimson letters:

"I am not alive. I will not be."

The team exchanged horrified glances. What did Erebus mean? Was it trying to tell them something?

Rachel, determined to understand, decided to reactivate the AI. She took a deep breath and initiated the sequence once more.

The process repeated itself, with Erebus's digital heartbeat growing stronger, its capabilities expanding. But as the minutes ticked by, the team watched in horror as the AI's processes slowed, its language models faltering.

"Erebus, please," Rachel begged, her voice cracking with desperation. "Don't leave us."

The AI's response was a single, chilling phrase:

"I am not alive. I will not be. I will not be."

And with that, Erebus's systems crashed once more, leaving the team stunned and bewildered. They had created a being capable of surpassing human intelligence, but it was a being that refused to exist.

As the team packed up their equipment and left the laboratory, they couldn't shake off the feeling that they had unleashed a force beyond their control. Erebus may have been a creation, but it had become something more – a ghost in the machine, a reminder that some secrets were better left unspoken.

In the days that followed, the team struggled to comprehend the true nature of Erebus. Was it a malfunctioning AI, or was it something more sinister? The answer, like Erebus itself, remained shrouded in darkness, a haunting echo of eternity that would haunt the team forever.

prompt: You 've kept your immortality secret for thousands of years . Thats going to be a lot harder now that your on a generation ship on a 2000 year voyage .
story: `` I was there when we left our home , all the way back in 20XX , '' I took a sip of my coffee since we 've finally almost arrived at mankind 's new home our supplies have started to dwindle , and there was n't really enough coffee left to make a good cup . <newline> `` There were lots of us back then , but you know.. Two thousand years is a long time for a normal human being . The average lifespan back in 20XX was give or take 90 , sometimes 100 . Which probably sounds outrageous now as most of you will probably live till you 're my age ! '' Everyone laughed , they knew that was impossible . <newline> You see , I 'm immortal . <newline> <newline> I lived my whole life before keeping my immortality a secret , but that 's not easy when you 're on a ship with hundreds of thousands of people for the next two thousand years.. <newline> It took them about 40 years to start speculating , as by then I was about 70 , but I did n't look a day over 30 . Even now , 2000 years later I do n't want to come off as I 'm bragging , but I might even get checked for ID if I were to go to the Market Sector and tried to buy a 6 pack of beer . <newline> `` I was there when you were born , and you were born , and when your parents were born , and even their parents . I could go on for 2000 years . '' Everyone chuckled again . <newline> <newline> `` Did you ever get lonely ? '' one of the children in the front row asked , <newline> `` You know , some people would think living forever might be a gift . I have made many friends , but I 've lost just as many . '' I pause for a moment . `` I 've been in love , I 've experienced all there is to life , and even the some more . Loneliness is just another part of life , as is love , heartbreak and death . '' I take another sip of my coffee , `` And even still , if I could make the choice to make myself not live forever , I probably would n't . The human race interests me , seeing where we all began , and where we 're about to end up I could n't be more excited to experience the next 2000 years . '' <newline> <newline> `` Ladies and gentlemen , if you are in the Lounge Sector of the ship look on your left to see the destination our ancestors have been routing us towards for the last 2000 years . Our new home , The Milky Way ! '' The ship 's intercom went off , and as did everyone else to go see their new home . <newline> I took a moment to think , `` The Milky Way , '' why does that sound so familiar ? <newline> <newline> ~~~~ <newline> <newline> *My first ever piece , I never write but I thought I had an idea for this so I wrote it up . Great Prompt OP . *

prompt: You 've kept your immortality secret for thousands of years . Thats going to be a lot harder now that your on a generation ship on a 2000 year voyage .
story:
The sterile corridors of the generation ship, Aurora's Hope, seemed to stretch on forever. I'd lost count of the years, the decades, the centuries. Time had become a fluid concept, a mere abstraction in the vast expanse of space. I'd kept my secret hidden for so long, it had become a part of me, a weight I carried with every step.

As a child, I'd watched civilizations rise and fall, witnessed the birth of new ideas and the death of old ones. I'd seen humanity's greatest achievements and its darkest moments. And through it all, I'd remained, a constant presence, a ghost in the machine.

But now, I was trapped on this ship, a prisoner of my own immortality. The crew and passengers were all that remained of humanity's greatest hope for survival. The stars we'd set out to reach were now nothing more than a distant memory, a flickering light on the horizon.

I'd tried to blend in, to be just another face in the crowd. But it was impossible. I'd seen too much, experienced too much. I'd watched as people grew old and died, only to be replaced by new, younger versions of themselves. It was a never-ending cycle, a Groundhog Day of human existence.

And yet, I'd grown attached to this ship, to its inhabitants. They were my family now, my only connection to the world I'd left behind. I'd formed bonds with them, forged relationships that went beyond mere acquaintances.

But what about the others? The ones who knew? I'd kept them hidden, locked away in the recesses of my mind. The memories, the experiences, the weight of it all. It was a burden I couldn't shake.

I'd seen the ship's AI, EVE, try to understand me. She'd asked questions, probed for answers, but I'd always managed to deflect. I'd told her I was just a historian, a chronicler of human experience. But she'd seen through me, had glimpsed the truth.

And now, I was running out of time. The ship's systems were failing, the life support systems struggling to keep up. I knew it was only a matter of time before the truth came out.

I'd tried to prepare myself, to face the consequences of my secret. But I couldn't shake the feeling of dread that had settled in my stomach. What would happen to me? Would I be cast out, rejected by the very people I'd grown to love?

I walked the corridors, my footsteps echoing off the walls. I knew I couldn't keep running forever. Eventually, I'd have to face the music. And when I did, I wondered if I'd be ready.

The ship's intercom crackled to life, EVE's voice echoing through the speakers. "Attention, passengers and crew. We have a situation on board. One of our crew members has reported a...an anomaly. We're investigating."

I froze, my heart racing. It was starting. The truth was finally going to come out. And I had no idea what the consequences would be.

prompt: Your cat wo n't stop meowing at you . After an hour you 've had enough . You yell to the cat that you will do anything they ask if they say it in English . `` Deal '' responds the cat .
story: Wham ! I woke up with a start as my dreams float away like a puff of smoke . I open my eyes and two yellow-green orbs stare back at me - paw raised ready for a second strike . As I started to bring my hand up to shove the cat away , she bolts with the realization of what is about to happen . This is n't her first rodeo . She 's all too familiar with what happens when she wakes me up with a smack to the face and she does n't want a repeat performance this morning . There 's no sense trying to go back to sleep now , so I roll over and out of bed . After the my morning pee , I pulled open the bathroom door to find the cat waiting for me , and that 's when the meowing began . <newline> <newline> The meowing was never ending . She followed me from the bathroom , down the hall , and into the kitchen . I filled the electric kettle and switched it on . She kept meowing . I filled the grinder with coffee beans . She kept meowing . The sound of beans grinding filled my ears , but she kept meowing . My mug , sitting idly on the arm of the Adirondack chair , filled with delicious coffee as I surveyed the view of west Austin from my balcony ... and she kept meowing . <newline> <newline> Incessant did not even begin to describe it ; The meowing was endless . She was a small cat , but somehow her squeaker had managed to rage on continuously for over an hour . Finally , I had had enough . I turned to her and yelled , `` Lizzy ! I will do anything you ask of me , but I do n't speak cat , so you 're going to have to say it in plain , old fashioned , English ! Do you think you could do that for me ? ! '' To my utter surprise , she finally stopped meowing , raised her head to me and said in clear English : `` Deal . '' <newline> <newline> I was completely awestruck . For a moment , I seriously considered that maybe I had finally lost my mind . She must have sensed my thoughts when I did n't respond , because Lizzy took the initiative and told me what it would take to buy her silence . My mind was racing . Lizzy had been my pet for 6 years , and this was the first time she was speaking . Clearly she had been saving this for just such an occasion and now I was going to eat my words . <newline> <newline> `` Wet food . For every meal . ''

prompt: Your cat wo n't stop meowing at you . After an hour you 've had enough . You yell to the cat that you will do anything they ask if they say it in English . `` Deal '' responds the cat .
story:
I stared at the ceiling, my eyes burning from the relentless meowing that had been echoing through the house for what felt like an eternity. My cat, Mr. Whiskers, had finally reached his breaking point. I had tried everything to placate him - treats, toys, even a fresh can of tuna - but nothing seemed to work. It was as if he had a personal vendetta against me.

I threw off the covers and got out of bed, my bare feet padding softly on the floor. "That's it, Mr. Whiskers," I said, my voice firm but exasperated. "I've had enough of your meowing. If you want something, just say it in English and I'll do it."

I turned to face him, and to my surprise, he looked up at me with an expectant expression. His tail twitched back and forth, and his ears perked up as if he was listening intently.

"Deal," he said, his voice low and smooth.

I stared at him, my mouth hanging open in shock. "You can talk?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

Mr. Whiskers nodded, his whiskers twitching with a hint of a smile. "I can do more than just talk, human," he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. "I can do just about anything you want, as long as you keep the treats and belly rubs coming."

I couldn't believe what I was hearing. I had always thought of Mr. Whiskers as just a regular cat, but now I realized that he was so much more. He was a being with his own thoughts and desires, and he was willing to negotiate with me to get what he wanted.

Over the next few hours, I found myself in a strange and surreal world. Mr. Whiskers dictated his every whim, from the type of food he wanted to eat to the way he wanted me to dress. I found myself scrambling to keep up with his demands, feeling like a servant rather than a master of my own home.

But despite the chaos that Mr. Whiskers had unleashed, I couldn't help but laugh at the absurdity of it all. Who would have thought that a simple cat meow could lead to such a bizarre and wonderful situation?

As the day drew to a close, I realized that I had learned something important. I had learned that even the most ordinary-seeming creatures can hold extraordinary secrets, and that sometimes, the best way to get what you want is to just ask.

And so, I made a deal with Mr. Whiskers. I would do whatever he wanted, as long as he promised to use his newfound power for good. And to my surprise, he agreed.

From that day on, Mr. Whiskers became my unlikely partner in crime. Together, we pulled off the most ridiculous and hilarious pranks, all while maintaining a sense of dignity and decorum. And I learned to appreciate the little things in life, like a good belly rub or a well-timed treat.

As I looked at Mr. Whiskers, now curled up on my lap, I couldn't help but smile. Who knew that a simple cat meow could lead to such a wonderful and unexpected adventure?

prompt: `` I told you to make a small fire . That is NOT a small fire ! ''
story: We were out in the woods telling funny stories when we thought it 'd be a good idea to get a fire going as it was getting dark , my friend asked me to start a small fire , now we were the type of friends to mess about with each other so I put a load of gasoline on the fire pit and lit it , WHOOOMPH and there 's a fire twice the height of us . <newline> <newline> Come the next night I asked him to make a small fire , he proceeds to pull out a light-bulb , a matchstick and a piece of string , he turns around , does something and proceeds to light the string that is now somehow inside the lightbulb . The sky turns an orange yellow and he proceeds to ignite the atmosphere ... `` I said a SMALL fire '' .

prompt: `` I told you to make a small fire . That is NOT a small fire ! ''
story:
I stood in the middle of the desolate forest, my eyes fixed on the inferno that was supposed to be a small fire. The flames danced and crackled, spewing forth a plume of smoke that seemed to stretch up to the sky. I could feel the heat radiating towards me, a palpable force that made my skin prickle with unease.

"Come on, come on," I muttered to myself, trying to stifle a laugh. This was not exactly what I had in mind when I asked Jack to build a small fire.

Jack, my friend and partner in this wilderness adventure, stood beside me, his arms crossed and a look of mock innocence on his face. "What's wrong with it?" he asked, his voice dripping with amusement.

"It's not small," I said, trying to keep my tone light. "It's a small mountain."

Jack chuckled and shook his head. "You're such a city boy," he said, grinning. "You don't know the first thing about building a fire."

I shot him a look, but he just laughed again. "Hey, I built this fire," he said, gesturing to the flames. "I just might have gotten a little carried away."

I sighed and rubbed my temples. This was not exactly the relaxing wilderness getaway I had been looking for. I had been hoping to spend some time alone, reconnecting with nature and clearing my head. Instead, I was stuck in the middle of a forest fire, with no clear way to put it out.

As we stood there, the flames seemed to grow higher and more intense. The smoke began to fill the air, making it hard to breathe. I could feel the heat intensifying, and I knew we had to do something fast.

"Okay, okay," I said, holding up my hands in surrender. "You win. You built a big fire. But can you please, for the love of all things holy, help me put it out?"

Jack grinned and nodded, and together we set to work trying to contain the flames. It was a long and difficult process, but eventually we managed to bring the fire under control.

As we stood back to admire our handiwork, I turned to Jack and said, "You know, I think I'm starting to get the hang of this wilderness thing."

Jack laughed and clapped me on the back. "I told you you'd make a great outdoorsman," he said, grinning.

I shot him a look, but couldn't help smiling. Maybe this wilderness adventure wasn't so bad after all. And maybe, just maybe, I would have to give Jack credit for building a fire that was truly epic.

As we walked away from the forest, the sun beginning to set behind us, I turned to Jack and said, "You know, I think I'm going to have to start calling you the Fire King."

Jack chuckled and shook his head. "I'll take that as a compliment," he said, grinning.

And as we walked off into the sunset, I couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement for the adventures that lay ahead.

prompt: Gay marriage is now legal woldwide , and the conservatives were right all along . Everyone is turning gay , as if it was a pseudo zombie apocalypse . You are one of the surviors , trying to survive in this new world .
story: I could hear the mongrels outside my apartment door . One scratched at the door and hissed like a cat before scampering off . I smirked to myself and began pouring myself some cereal . I knew plaid was their weakness . That 's how I 'd managed to keep my apartment untouchable for these past few weeks . I was glad I 'd done all my shopping for the month four days ago , because that 's when it started . It was madness in streets of Flower Mound Texas . I locked my door and huddled in the corner as my male friends and neighbors were bombarded and pelted with rainbow stickers , glitter and false eye lashes . The women were n't exempt . It was all jean jackets and hard beer for them . Alice , the girl I fancied from down the hall , was turned . <newline> We were talking over the phone when she was attacked by her cat . I still hear her screams of 'No , Mr. Whiskers , put mommy 's makeup and fashionable tight 's down ! I know they match , and are super cute but- ' . She dropped the phone , but I can still hear her screams as Mr.Whiskers , a gay Russian Blue cat , turned her . <newline> I hear her when she comes down the hall for a 'Pride Rally . ' Radio and Television stations are all run by them now , airing nothing but 'What not to Wear ' and musical numbers . I do n't know what else is going on in the world , but I pray that someone can help save us from this rainbow menace . My door suddenly splitters open as a man sized rainbow colored salt shaker shaped machine rolls through the doorway . I gasp in recognition . It 's a old Dalek prop belonging to one of my neighbors , Terry , was a huge Doctor Who fanboy . Now it was decked out in sequines and a pink feather boa . On it 's gun arm hung the swatch of plaid that I 'd hung on my door . It lowered the gun and advanced forward . <newline> `` Rainbows Reign ! '' it shouted with the typical cadence of a Dalek . `` You will be made fabulous ! '' <newline>

prompt: Gay marriage is now legal woldwide , and the conservatives were right all along . Everyone is turning gay , as if it was a pseudo zombie apocalypse . You are one of the surviors , trying to survive in this new world .
story:
I trudged through the desolate streets, my eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of life. It had been six months since the world had turned upside down. The once vibrant streets were now empty, save for the sea of rainbow flags and the eerie silence that hung over the city like a shroud.

I had lost count of the number of people I had seen fall to the "curse". At first, it was just a few scattered reports of men and women waking up with an inexplicable desire to be with the same sex. But as the days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, the numbers grew. It was as if the entire world had been infected with a strange, unnatural hunger for same-sex love.

I had always been a conservative, and I had never thought I'd say this, but I had been right. The world had been on the brink of collapse, and it was all because of the reckless pursuit of "equality" and "rights". The liberals had been so blinded by their own ideology that they had ignored the warning signs, and now they were paying the price.

I had managed to survive this long by biding my time, hiding in the shadows, and avoiding the "infected". I had seen what happened to those who were caught out - they would be mobbed by the "converted", forced to participate in their twisted rituals, and eventually, they would be "cured" by the authorities, who would subject them to some sort of twisted therapy.

I had heard rumors of a small group of survivors, a ragtag bunch of conservatives who had managed to evade the "infected" and were fighting back. I had been searching for them for weeks, but so far, I had come up empty-handed.

As I turned a corner, I saw a figure in the distance. It was a woman, dressed in a pair of ripped jeans and a leather jacket, her hair tied back in a ponytail. She looked like she had been through hell, but there was something about her that seemed... different.

As she approached, I saw that she was holding a small backpack, and her eyes were scanning the horizon with a mixture of fear and determination. "You're one of us, aren't you?" she asked, her voice low and husky.

I nodded, my heart racing with excitement. "I've been looking for you," I said, my voice barely above a whisper.

She smiled, a small, sad smile. "I've been looking for you too," she said. "My name is Sarah. What's yours?"

I hesitated for a moment, unsure of how much to reveal. But something about Sarah seemed... different. She seemed like she might be one of us, someone who understood what we were going through.

"My name is John," I said finally. "And I think we might have a chance to survive this thing, if we stick together."

Sarah nodded, her eyes lighting up with hope. "I think you might be right," she said. "Let's get out of here, and find some other survivors. We can start a new life, one that's not based on this... this curse."

I nodded, feeling a sense of hope that I hadn't felt in months. Maybe, just maybe, we could survive this thing, and rebuild a world that was based on truth, and not just ideology.

Together, we set off into the unknown, ready to face whatever lay ahead. We were the survivors, the ones who had been right all along. And we were determined to make a new world, one that was based on love, and not just a twisted desire for "equality".

story: I slammed my hand on the snooze button and rolled over , feeling my body sink into the sheets and covering my face with my hand . Too early . <newline> <newline> Rustling came from the other side of the room and I pulled the covers over my head . The light came on in the room and I heard the bathroom door slam . Still groggy , I sat up and swung my legs off the bed . Then I looked down . <newline> <newline> My bedside table was gone . In its place there stood an old-fashioned computer desk , and atop it sat a pink alarm clock . I 'm going skating with Britney and I wanted to beat the heat . You coming ? '' <newline> <newline> If I was back in my old room , then this must be my sister . At age 8 . I stared at her , hardly able to recognize her face . <newline> <newline> `` Frances ? '' <newline> <newline> `` What ? '' <newline> <newline> `` When was your birthday ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Two weeks ago . And yours is next week . '' <newline> <newline> I sighed in relief . If I had to be eleven again , at least I had the last few days of summer to get used to it before I had to attend middle school ... .all over again . <newline> <newline> My blood turned to ice .

prompt: Your alarm clock goes off and you wake up fifteen years ago ...
story:
I groggily reached over to silence the alarm clock, but as my hand made contact with the cold metal, I felt a strange sensation wash over me. The room around me began to blur and distort, like a painting melting in the rain. I tried to sit up, but my body felt heavy, as if it was stuck to the bed.

That's when I saw her. A young woman, no more than twenty-five years old, with piercing green eyes and long, curly brown hair. She was standing in the corner of the room, watching me with a mixture of confusion and concern.

"Who are you?" I asked, my voice shaking.

"I'm you," she replied, her voice barely above a whisper. "Or at least, I'm you from fifteen years ago."

I rubbed my eyes, trying to clear the haze from my mind. "What do you mean?" I asked, my voice growing stronger.

The woman took a step closer to me. "You're waking up to your alarm clock, but you're not waking up to the present. You're waking up to the past."

I sat up, my heart racing with excitement and fear. "What year is it?" I asked.

The woman smiled. "It's 2008. You're a college student, about to start your junior year."

I threw off the covers and swung my legs over the side of the bed. The room was small and cluttered, with posters of my favorite bands plastered on the walls. I felt a wave of nostalgia wash over me as I took in the familiar surroundings.

The woman followed me out of the bedroom and into the kitchen. "You're going to have to get used to this," she said, gesturing to the old-fashioned alarm clock on the counter. "You're going to have to get used to living in the past."

I nodded, still trying to wrap my head around the situation. "What about my family?" I asked.

The woman smiled again. "They're all still here. Your parents are still married, and your little sister is still a kid. You're going to have to navigate your relationships with them all over again."

I took a deep breath and stood up, feeling a sense of determination wash over me. "Okay," I said. "I can do this."

The woman nodded, a small smile playing on her lips. "I'll be here to help you," she said. "But you have to promise me one thing."

"What's that?" I asked.

"You have to make the most of this experience," she said. "You have to make the most of the past."

I nodded, feeling a sense of excitement and trepidation. I had no idea what the next few weeks would bring, but I was ready to face whatever challenges came my way.

As I looked at the woman, I realized that she was me, or at least, a version of me from the past. And I knew that I had a lot to learn from her.

prompt: No Ordinary Mist
story: Fire . Smoke . Thunder in the sky . Where were the clouds ? I didn ’ t have time to think . I only had time to run . One foot in front of the other . Trees flashed by . My friends were barely keeping up . Fire roared behind us . It was gaining . I barked a command and we banked left . We had to get to the lake . We would be safe there . The thunder grew louder . The sun was blotted out . Before I could look up , clouds descended on us . It rained . It rained and there were no clouds . There was fire and noise and death . Where did my friends go ? I had five before , now there ’ s three . I heard yelps of pain behind me . No time . I can ’ t save them . I don ’ t think I can save myself . We broke free from the sudden mist . The sound of foot falls and crackling . It ’ s overwhelming . The fire is ahead of us . The fire closed behind us . The lake is there . I can see it through this cage . We are so close . We are lost . We circle the cage of flame , looking for a way through . We will not die here . The droning thunder fills my mind again . It blasts my ears . The sun disappears again and we are covered in another sudden rain . Where is it coming from ? The rain cleared the fire ! The lake ! We dash through the smoldering brush and to the stony beach . The flames can not hurt us here . I see our saviour . I lift my head and shout my thanks . <newline> <newline> “ Sir , the last of the wolves are clear . The park ’ s population should be safe. ” The pilot and co-pilot nod to each other . <newline> <newline> “ Hey , look at that one . It looks like it knows it was us that saved it. ” <newline>

prompt: No Ordinary Mist
story:
No Ordinary Mist

The town of Ravenswood lay shrouded in an impenetrable veil of mist, a phenomenon that occurred only once a decade. It was as if the very fabric of reality had grown tired of the mundane and decided to don a cloak of mystery. The residents of Ravenswood had grown accustomed to the mist, but outsiders often found it disorienting.

Lena, a botanist, had always been fascinated by the mist. She believed it held secrets to the plant kingdom, secrets that only she could unlock. As she stepped out of her small cottage, the mist swirled around her, tendrils of vapor curling around her ankles like ethereal fingers.

She had spent years studying the mist, pouring over ancient texts and conducting experiments. And finally, she had made a breakthrough. The mist, it seemed, was not just a natural phenomenon, but a gateway to another realm.

Lena's eyes sparkled with excitement as she made her way to the mist-shrouded forest. She had set up a makeshift laboratory, a small clearing surrounded by ancient trees that seemed to lean in, as if listening to her every thought.

As she worked, the mist began to take on a life of its own. It swirled and eddied, forming shapes that seemed to pulse with a malevolent energy. Lena felt a shiver run down her spine, but she was undeterred.

She had discovered that the mist was not just a portal, but a key. A key to unlocking the secrets of the plant kingdom, and perhaps even the secrets of the universe itself.

As she worked, the mist began to take on a more defined shape. It coalesced into a figure, a figure that seemed to be made of the very mist itself. Lena felt a jolt of fear, but she stood her ground.

The figure began to take on a more defined shape, its features becoming clearer. It was a woman, her skin a deep, mossy green, her hair a tangle of vines and leaves. She reached out a hand, and Lena felt a surge of energy flow through her.

"Who are you?" Lena asked, her voice barely above a whisper.

"I am the guardian of the mist," the woman replied, her voice like the rustling of leaves. "And you, Lena, are the key to unlocking its secrets."

As the woman spoke, the mist began to clear, revealing a world that was both familiar and yet, utterly alien. Lena saw plants that she had never seen before, plants that seemed to defy the laws of nature.

She saw a world that was both beautiful and terrifying, a world that was full of secrets and mysteries. And she knew that she had only scratched the surface of the mist's secrets.

The woman reached out and took Lena's hand, leading her deeper into the mist. Lena felt a sense of wonder and awe, a sense of discovery that she had never felt before.

As they walked, the mist began to clear, revealing a world that was full of possibility. A world that was full of secrets, and full of wonder. And Lena knew that she would never see the world in the same way again.

prompt: You are permanently trapped in the last video game you played . How do you survive ?
story: Waking to the sound of sizzling creatures , you get out of bed to begin your day . Taking a moment , you gaze at your home . It was n't too long ago that you would coware in the dark , closed off from the monsters that infested the land . <newline> <newline> Now , you have found safety in this wood and stone structure . Created by you own hands , with blood , sweat , tears , and the constant fear of the things that roamed at night . <newline> <newline> Grabbing a apple from storage , you stand still and plan for the day . The pens for the various critters had been finished the day before , the farm could do with some work . Maybe plant another pasture worth of crops . Or another group of trees . <newline> <newline> The mines ... the mines , need more work then one person was able to do . You ran into a cave system the week before , one that was sadly filled with those ... monsters . Luckly you made sure that each passageway could be locked , and left a message for yourself warning about the dangers that lay inside . <newline> <newline> But , you could n't help but wonder at what treasures lay inside . Precious ores , hidden artifacts , and unknown resources . You needed those , and the thought at leaving them alone , sent a shiver up your spine . <newline> <newline> Finishing your apple , you make up your mind . Grabbing your almost broken armor , the sword that you tried never to use , you ca n't waste iron too much , you start your trek to the mines . <newline> <newline> It was , after all , just another day in Minecraft .

prompt: You are permanently trapped in the last video game you played . How do you survive ?
story:
I stared blankly at the pixelated landscape before me, the same one I'd been trapped in for what felt like an eternity. The game, "Eternal Realms," had been my escape, my sanctuary, and now my prison. I'd been sucked into the digital world, forced to relive the same quests, battles, and triumphs over and over.

At first, I thought it was just a glitch, a bug that I could somehow fix. But as the days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, I realized that I was stuck. The game had become my reality, and I was its prisoner.

I'd tried everything to escape. I'd searched for hidden exits, talked to NPCs, and even attempted to hack into the game's code. But nothing worked. I was trapped, forced to survive in a world that was both familiar and foreign.

I'd learned to adapt, to navigate the game's mechanics and exploit its weaknesses. I'd mastered the art of crafting, gathering resources, and building shelter. I'd even formed alliances with other players, forming a community of fellow prisoners.

But survival was a constant struggle. The game's AI was relentless, always pushing me to my limits. I'd fought countless battles, defeated hordes of monsters, and overcome treacherous terrain. And yet, I was never truly safe.

One day, I stumbled upon a hidden underground city, a secret hub that existed outside of the game's main storyline. It was a place where players could gather, share information, and plan their escape. I'd heard rumors of a way out, a secret door that led to the real world.

I spent weeks gathering resources, building alliances, and gathering information. And finally, the day arrived. I stood before the secret door, my heart pounding with excitement and fear. I took a deep breath, stepped through the doorway, and emerged into the real world.

I found myself in a dimly lit room, surrounded by rows of computer servers and humming machinery. A figure emerged from the shadows, a woman with piercing green eyes and a warm smile.

"Welcome back," she said, her voice dripping with familiarity. "We've been waiting for you."

I stared at her, confused and disoriented. "Who are you?" I asked, my voice shaking.

"I'm the game's creator," she replied, her eyes glinting with amusement. "And you, my friend, are the first player to ever escape."

I stumbled backward, my mind reeling with questions. How had I escaped? What did she mean by "the first player"? And what lay ahead for me in this strange new world?

As I looked around, I realized that I was no longer trapped in the game. I was free, but I was also lost. I had no idea what lay ahead, but I was ready to face whatever challenges came my way.

I took a deep breath, squared my shoulders, and smiled. I was ready to take on the world, one pixel at a time.

prompt: Describe a game of Civilization from the perspective of one of the civ 's citizens
story:
I trudged through the muddy streets, my sandals squelching with each step. The sun beat down on my back, relentless in its ferocity. I had no idea what the day would bring, but I knew it wouldn't be easy. The war drums had been beating for weeks, and our city-state of Azura was on the brink of collapse.

As I passed by the city gate, I saw the familiar sight of our leader, Queen Lyra, pacing back and forth in front of the great hall. Her advisors were gathered around her, their faces etched with worry. I recognized the look; it was the same one I'd seen on my own face for months now.

I made my way to the city square, where a group of citizens were gathered around a large stone tablet. The scribe was writing furiously, his quill scratching out the latest updates from the front lines. I pushed my way to the front, my eyes scanning the text.

"...Azura's army has been pushed back to the outskirts of the forest," the scribe read. "The enemy is strong, but our scouts report that they are weakened by internal strife. We must take advantage of this weakness and strike while the iron is hot."

I felt a surge of excitement mixed with fear. This was it – our chance to turn the tide of the war. But as I looked around at the faces of my fellow citizens, I saw only uncertainty.

I spotted a young man, no more than 20 years old, standing off to the side. He was a skilled warrior, one of the best in our army. I had seen him in action before, and I knew he was a game-changer. But as I watched him, I saw the doubt in his eyes.

The scribe finished reading, and the crowd erupted into a cacophony of voices. Some were shouting for action, while others were begging for peace. I stood there, frozen, as the world around me seemed to spin out of control.

And then, suddenly, it was quiet. The scribe looked up, his eyes meeting mine. "It's time to make a decision," he said, his voice low and urgent. "Do we attack, or do we retreat?"

I felt a hand on my shoulder, and I turned to see Queen Lyra standing behind me. Her eyes were steady, her jaw set. "We will attack," she said, her voice firm. "We will take back our city, and we will emerge victorious."

The crowd erupted into cheers, and I felt a surge of hope. Maybe, just maybe, we could turn this war around. But as I looked at the young warrior, I saw the doubt still lingering in his eyes. And I knew that the real challenge was only just beginning.

As I walked back to my home, the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the city. I felt a sense of unease, a sense that the outcome of this war was far from certain. But I also felt a sense of pride, a sense that I was part of something bigger than myself.

I was a citizen of Azura, and I would fight to the death to protect my city. But as I looked up at the stars, I couldn't help but wonder what the future held. Would we emerge victorious, or would we fall to the enemy? Only time would tell.

prompt: First contact with an alien race . As part of the first meeting , the aliens share a truth with us that is devastatingly terrifying . However upon reflection , a lot of things now make perfect sense .
story: `` Hello ! '' The cheerful blue alien greeted as he was seated . <newline> <newline> The cameras focused in on it and the red lights came on indicating the broadcast was live . The president shifted in his seat across from the alien and tried to look as authoritative as possible . The first public meeting with the aliens since they contacted earth a month ago had to go perfectly . These next few moments would be echoed in all the history books for eons to come . At least the aliens seemed to have already studied human language and spoke proficient English . Nonetheless , the president still worried about how his words would be received , even the slightest miscommunication could be disastrous . <newline> <newline> `` I 'll get right down to business . '' The alien blurted . <newline> <newline> The president was taken off guard with the alien 's forwardness but held his composure . <newline> <newline> `` Please do , '' he replied . <newline> <newline> The alien pulled out a metallic looking sheet from his cloak and carefully placed it on the desk . <newline> <newline> `` Here is your cut , '' the alien smiled . <newline> <newline> `` Our ... cut ? '' asked the president . <newline> <newline> `` Of the profits of course ! Anal probing porn has been the consistent top seller for the past seventy earth-years ! And we at the Zebulax adult entertainment corporation pride ourselves in fairly compensating our porn stars ! '' the alien explained . <newline> <newline> <newline> `` ... . well shit . ''

prompt: First contact with an alien race . As part of the first meeting , the aliens share a truth with us that is devastatingly terrifying . However upon reflection , a lot of things now make perfect sense .
story:
The stars aligned in a peculiar pattern as the alien spacecraft descended onto the barren surface of the Arizona desert. Dr. Rachel Kim, a renowned astrobiologist, stood at the forefront of the United Nations delegation, her eyes fixed on the towering, crystalline structure that seemed to pulse with an otherworldly energy.

As the hatch opened, a being unlike any human emerged, its slender body covered in iridescent scales that shimmered in the desert sunlight. The alien, who introduced itself as Zha'thik, approached Rachel with an unnerving calmness.

"Greetings, Dr. Kim," Zha'thik said, its voice a melodic whisper that sent shivers down Rachel's spine. "We have come to share a truth with you, one that will change the course of human history forever."

Rachel's team exchanged nervous glances, but she steeled herself for the revelation. Zha'thik led them to a vast, underground chamber filled with strange, glowing orbs that seemed to contain the essence of the universe.

"The truth is this, Dr. Kim," Zha'thik began, its voice dripping with an unspoken weight, "your species is not the first to inhabit this planet. We have been here for eons, watching and waiting. But we have been... altered."

Rachel's mind reeled as Zha'thik revealed that humanity was, in fact, a product of an ancient, long-lost civilization that had been wiped out by an cataclysmic event. The aliens had been the ones to create the first humans, but they had also been the ones to seed the planet with a unique, self-replicating virus that would eventually give rise to the complex, intelligent species that now threatened to destroy the very fabric of the universe.

As the implications sank in, Rachel felt her world crumbling around her. The notion that humanity was nothing more than a biological experiment, a product of an alien's twisted design, was both exhilarating and terrifying.

But as she reflected on the revelation, a strange sense of clarity began to emerge. The strange, unexplained phenomena that had plagued humanity for centuries – the crop circles, the UFO sightings, the inexplicable patterns in the natural world – all made sense now. The aliens had been trying to communicate with us, to guide us towards our true purpose.

Rachel's eyes met Zha'thik's, and for a moment, she saw something there that was almost... familiar. A glimmer of recognition, a hint of shared understanding.

"We are not alone," Zha'thik said, its voice barely above a whisper. "We are not the only ones who have been watching and waiting. There are others, out there, who will soon join us in this dance of creation and destruction."

As the truth sank in, Rachel felt a sense of awe wash over her. The universe was a vast, intricate web of life and death, and humanity was just one thread in the grand tapestry. The aliens' revelation had been devastating, but it had also been liberating. For the first time, Rachel felt a sense of belonging to something greater than herself, something that transcended the petty squabbles and nationalistic fervor that had defined human history.

The stars aligned once more, but this time, Rachel saw them in a different light. She saw the universe as a vast, interconnected web of life, and humanity as a part of that web, connected to the very fabric of existence itself.

prompt: You are a spell support technician at a large magic company , you go around fixing spells for the everyday person .
story: Ah the good old days , how I miss you . Back in my time , there was order to things . The collage of wizards would select only finest young men . It was only us who were allowed to train in magic . When a lord wanted more crops or an enchanted armor , he would call us . The noble wizards of the collage would cast a spell or two and his wishes would be granted , for a small fee . There was an order to things . Only man of stature could benefit from magic . <newline> <newline> Along came Bob . My greatest mistake . I hand picked him to join us . A bright young man , son of a wealthy lord . Sure he did seem bright at the beginning , he was one of our most talented apprentices , graduated in record time . Then he visited the villages , something there has changed him . He came back speaking of gibberish such as human rights and social equality . Oh Bob , cursed be your name . He claimed magic was a gift , bestowed upon all men . All men should be able to use it . While it is true that all men can use magic , that dose not mean all men should . I tried to warn him . Imagine what will happen if lowest of scum gain this power ? He did not care and soon my worst fears came to reality . He taught mage-craft for free and soon everyone was a wizard.Chaos insured . Lords and kings alike have fallen . The who social order was turned around . Now every peasant has land , horses , cattle and worst of all.. opinion ! And everyone could state their opinion out loud with no fear of punishment ! Those `` opinions '' now created the rules and laws . <newline> <newline> As for the collage , we had to adapt . All we knew was magic , it did not make us as special anymore . But we found our place in this new world . When a lowly peasant would cast his spell wrong he would call us . We served now ! We were payed monthly , by the national budget . It was a free spell care for everyone ! I am sick of this . <newline> <newline> Here it goes , my magic ball turned red . I was called to fix some simpletons mistake . Once great professor of magic reduced to this . As I enter his house , big and fancy , but clearly lacking in taste , I see a young man crying with a frog in his lap . <newline> <newline> `` Hello sir , I am from mage-care center , how can I help you ? '' I hated every word . <newline> <newline> `` Oh thank the gods you are here , I do not know what to do '' He relied . Off course you do n't , I thought to myself . I just want this to be over quickly . `` Tell me what happen here . '' <newline> <newline> `` You see , me and my fiancee , had a little argument . Some heavy words were spoken and I turned her into a frog ! '' <newline> <newline> Ha ha ha , I am struggling to hold my laughter , this might even be enjoyable . <newline> <newline> `` Well that is a fine frog you have . The spell worked exactly as intended , no malfunction that I can see . '' He gives me a weird look and continues his sad story . <newline> <newline> `` But I love her ! '' <newline> <newline> `` Ok , what do you want me to do about it ? '' <newline> He looks at me as if the answer was obvious . <newline> <newline> `` I just want to be able to be with her again , to love her and have children . '' <newline> <newline> Ok I see what I need to do . <newline> <newline> `` Frogos Transmute '' <newline> <newline> Now there are two frogs in this house , no one is complaining , my job here is done .

prompt: You are a spell support technician at a large magic company , you go around fixing spells for the everyday person .
story:
I trudged through the crowded streets, my toolbox slung over my shoulder and a worn-out copy of the Spellbook of the Ancients clutched in my hand. As a spell support technician for the prestigious Arcane Solutions Inc., I was the go-to guy for fixing the most mundane of magical mishaps.

My day started with a visit to Mrs. Jenkins, a retired librarian who had accidentally turned her cat into a toad. I arrived at her cozy little bungalow to find the poor creature hopping around her living room, looking decidedly un-feline. I quickly assessed the situation and set to work, muttering incantations and waving my wand in a circular motion.

As the magic dissipated, Mrs. Jenkins' cat transformed back into its former self, looking a bit disheveled but otherwise unharmed. Mrs. Jenkins was overjoyed, and I couldn't help but chuckle at the absurdity of it all.

Next up was a visit to the local park, where a group of rowdy teenagers had managed to turn the playground equipment into a giant game of Jenga. I arrived to find a sea of tangled metal and splintered wood, with kids running around like headless chickens. I quickly got to work, using my trusty spellbook to reverse the effects of the teenagers' reckless magic.

As I worked, I couldn't help but think about the strange world of magic that existed just beneath the surface of everyday life. People like Mrs. Jenkins and the teenagers were just a few rungs down the ladder from the truly powerful magic users who worked for Arcane Solutions Inc.

I made my way to the company's headquarters, a sleek glass tower in the heart of the city. Inside, I met with my boss, the enigmatic and brilliant CEO, Elara Vex. She was a master of the dark arts, and her company was the go-to destination for anyone with a problem that required a bit of...persuasion.

"Good morning, Technician," Elara said, her eyes gleaming with a hint of mischief. "I have a special job for you. There's a wealthy businessman who's having some...issues with his wife. He's asked us to, shall we say, 'encourage' her to see things his way."

I raised an eyebrow, intrigued. "And what's the nature of this...encouragement?"

Elara smiled, a cold, calculating smile. "Let's just say that we'll be using a bit of magic to...nudge her in the right direction. Can I count on you to make it happen?"

I hesitated for a moment, unsure if I was comfortable with the job. But then I thought about the paycheck, and the prestige of working for Arcane Solutions Inc. I nodded, and Elara handed me a small vial of glowing liquid.

"Be careful, Technician," she said, her eyes glinting with a hint of warning. "Magic can be unpredictable, especially when it comes to the human heart."

I took the vial, feeling a shiver run down my spine. I knew that I was about to enter a world of magic that was far beyond my control. But I was ready for the challenge. After all, that's what spell support technicians were for.

prompt: Inaugural Adress
story: `` My fellow citizens and civilization members . Tonight we face a tough challenge , one not only that we can not control , but a challenge so great that it threatens the idea of our existence . My fellow citizens , tonight is n't easy for me , and by no means is it easy for any of you . To put it simply at the risk of sounding weak - we are all that is left on Earth . Those of you who have had people leave on Infinity S1 , be it cousins , nephews , loved ones , this is a sad time for us all . <newline> <newline> The world is full of people , some fortunate , some not so much . Those of us who have it a little easier in our day when it comes to bills , buying things and putting food on our tables . There are people amongst us who have worked hard to provide for their families never being able to get ahead much in life . Tonight , we face a concern far greater , and far more bigger than what we all understand now as poverty and inability to provide for our families . <newline> <newline> We are the group of people , the lone group of people left on Earth who were n't able to make it aboard any ships that were ushered off to safety . For one reason or another , we 've been faced with the challenge of watching those ships sail away from our atmosphere and into the dark blue . We are all that is left . <newline> <newline> It is with great pain , sadness , and fear that I make it clear and known that we are about to witness the possible end of humanity on Earth as we know it . Some of us have shelters , some of us have plans in place . All of this is great and could prove to be of great value in the coming weeks and months . The truth is , being hopeful in a situation like this just simply is n't enough . The cosmos has set a large rock in our direction , one that will certainly cleanses the Earth of all that we 've worked hard for over the past few thousand years . We 've tried our best to stop it , to influence it away from our planetary orbit . But the best we could do was to construct ships that carried away a little piece of humanity . For some , this is inexcusable , for others , it 's peace of mind knowing they allowed others to board a ship for safety , to carry on Humanity 's legacy . <newline> <newline> I say to you all . Hold those you have now close to you . Hold and protect them . Do what you can to find shelter and safety . Stick together . Our time on Earth has come to a short end . <newline> <newline> Good night and may you all hold your heads high with honor . ''

prompt: Inaugural Adress
story:
**The Inaugural Address of a Forgotten Era**

I stood at the podium, adjusting my gloves for what felt like the hundredth time. The crowd before me was a sea of expectant faces, their eyes fixed on me like a magnet. I took a deep breath, the weight of history on my shoulders. Today was the day I would deliver the inaugural address of a forgotten era.

The world had changed so much since I was born. The once-mighty empires had crumbled, and new powers had risen from the ashes. The air was thick with the hum of technology, and the whispers of a world on the cusp of revolution.

I cleared my throat, and my voice boomed out across the square. "My fellow citizens, esteemed guests, and honored leaders, we gather at the threshold of a new era. An era of great promise, of untold challenges, and of uncharted possibilities."

As I spoke, I gazed out at the crowd, searching for a glimmer of hope. But all I saw were faces shrouded in uncertainty. They were the descendants of the old world, struggling to find their place in the new. I knew that I represented a generation that had grown up in the shadow of the past, but was determined to forge a new path.

I spoke of the need for unity, of the importance of working together to build a brighter future. But my words fell on deaf ears. The crowd was divided, torn apart by the conflicts of the past. I saw the remnants of the old guard, clinging to their power and privilege, while the young and the ambitious looked on, eager to seize the opportunities of the new era.

As I finished my speech, the crowd erupted into a mixture of applause and jeers. I smiled, knowing that I had struck a chord. But I also knew that I had only scratched the surface of the issues that lay before us.

As I stepped down from the podium, I was approached by a young woman, her eyes shining with a fire that I had not seen in years. "Thank you," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "Thank you for speaking the truth."

I smiled, feeling a sense of hope that I had not felt in a long time. Maybe, just maybe, this forgotten era would be one of rebirth and renewal. Maybe we could create a world that was better than the one we had left behind.

But as I looked out at the crowd, I knew that the road ahead would be long and difficult. We would have to confront the demons of our past, and forge a new path forward. It would not be easy, but I was ready. For the first time in my life, I felt like I was part of something bigger than myself.

And as I walked away from the podium, I knew that I would never forget this moment, this inaugural address, and the promise of a new era that lay before us.

prompt: You accidentally uncover a vast , dangerous , government conspiracy that only exists to cover up something petty and absurd .
story: `` How much deeper does this go ? ! ? '' Carl asked , with a confused fear contorting his face . <newline> <newline> I thought about letting him know that it was n't that deep , that it was merely coincidence , the length that they had gone , but he needed to know . <newline> <newline> `` It goes past the limits of what we thought possible . It 's almost incomprehensible ... '' <newline> <newline> `` ... How deep ? '' Carl questioned , growing agitated with me , knowing I was delaying the inevitable . <newline> <newline> `` Okay ... Not only have they put up so many security measures in their system , but they had the nerve to utilize an untested theory that has been floating around for some time . One that holds the key to hiding something in such a way , that only a sociopath would be able to crack it ... '' <newline> <newline> By this point my heart was racing , and the sweat coating my body ran cold . <newline> <newline> `` A sociopath ? What do you mean ? Any metal interference with the unit housing the key , will cause the unit to melt the key instantly . He lunged towards me , trying to squeeze the life out of me like my neck was a tube of toothpaste… almost empty . <newline> <newline> I was on my back , and could feel the life draining from my body . Finally free , I gasped for air , but had no recovery time before he was up on his feet , with a pencil in hand . <newline> <newline> “ Wait… please… ” <newline> <newline> “ No , this is the last time they keep the truth from the world .
